bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, October 10, 1940

div1.p: Andrus comments on Truby's draft about his Cuba experiences, especially in regards to Agramonte.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, October 10, 1940
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
10-10-40
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter of the first and thank you for send-
ing me the draft of your experiences in Cuba. I found it
intensely interesting. It did not arrive until yesterday,
so I have had time to do no more than read it through.

Am afraid you will be disappointed in the little help I will
be able to give you.

Your manuscript has cleared up one subject that has been beyond
my comprehension for years. I have a copy of volume 61,
Senate Documents, 61st. Congress, 3rd. session (1911) It is
probable that you also have a copy. On pages 25 and 26, the
Surgeon General quotes a letter from Dr. Agramonte from which
I take the following extract:

“While the experimental station, afterward named Camp
Lazear, in honor to the memory of our deceased colleague,
was being established, the care of the mosquitoes and
their infection by applying them to yellow fever cases,
was in the hands of Dr. Agramonte, at the division lab-
oratory; when the permanent ‘mosquito building’ was
erected at Camp Lazear (Dec. 1, 1900), these mosquitoes
were turned over to Dr. Carroll for his care. It de-
volved then upon Dr. Agramonte to select the mosquitoes
from thosemkept by Dr. Carroll and apply them to non-
immunes, as well as to make all subsequent direct
innoculations, and to obtain the non-immunes (Spaniards)
for the purpose, until the end of the work in Cuba.”

From early October, 1900, until I was innoculated Jan. 25, 1901,
I was on duty in Major Reed's laboratory every day and my main
job was to “raise” mosquitoes. Early in the experiments,
mosquitoes may have been procured by and innoculated by Dr. Agramonte.
Later - and during the major part of the experimental work -
mosquitoes we had raised were innoculated by Major Reed, or
Dr. Ames from experimental cases.

Volunteers were innoculated by mosquito AT Camp Lazear, after
having been in quarantine there. Those innoculated by blood
injection were taken from quarantine at Camp Lazear to OUTSIDE
one of the yellow fever wards and, after innoculation, were
rushed back to Camp Lazear. Dr. Agramonte was rarely at
Camp Lazear - his work, as you know, was elsewhere - so - - -
When I first found Dr. Agramonte's statement, in 1937, I
tried to check it with some of the volunteers but did not
get satisfactory information.

Then I thought I would see if Steward Neate was where I could
reach him. I wrote to the Surgeon General's office but
asked about Steward Neall. (The name did not ring quite
right but was as near as I could get to it.)

Now, that you have given me the correct name, I wrote yester-
day and, if I succeed in getting in touch with him, will see
if he cannot settle the question.

I made a sketch of the layout of the post hospital at Colum-
bia Barracks and a tracing of your sketch and have sent both
to Lambert with the request that he insert the yellow fever
hospital buildings and anything else that we have omitted.

Incidentally, I have a photograph (approximately 8 x 10) of
operating room and wards. It does not show officers' quar-
ters, barracks or other buildings. Do you want it?
You are welcome to it if it will be of any use.

A correction I will show when I return your manuscript is that
I did not serve with Major Reed's Board after my innoculation
and, of course, did NOT return, with him, to Washington.

Number 15, in the group photograph, is John Morris. His
home is (or was) in Reading, Pa. He called on me two or
three times but not within the last couple of years.
From the heavy-weight he was when the photograph was taken,
he shriveled to almost nothing. He made a career of the
Army and retired a hospital sergeant.

If you need your manuscript before I get it back to you, just
let me know. You said there was no hurry and I shall take
you at your word.
And please let me know if you want the hospital photograph.
